prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. So the question is whether the author is in the wrong for wanting his girlfriend to start paying some bills after a single incident where she had to pay for takeout. 

First, I need to look at the situation. The author and his girlfriend live together. He's paying all the rent and bills because she only works part-time. The issue started when he forgot his wallet and asked her to pay for under $40 takeout. She was upset about it, and now he's considering making her contribute more, even though he acknowledges she can't pay a lot.

So, why might he be in the wrong? Well, he's reacting to one incident. Maybe he's being unfair because one time doesn't establish a pattern. The fact that she only works part-time means her income is limited. If he's been paying everything all along, it's possible he didn't set clear expectations about splitting expenses. Maybe he's been taking on all the financial responsibility without discussing it, and now he's upset about a small amount. The tone he describes her having might be because she suddenly has to pay something, which is new, and she might feel it's unfair or unexpected.

On the other hand, maybe he's right to want her to contribute. Even a small amount could help, and it's about fairness. If she's living there, it's reasonable for her to help with costs. However, the approach of making her pay because of a single incident could be harsh. The author might need to communicate better instead of lashing out over a minor issue. Also, the fact that he's been paying everything before could mean the problem is more about his changing expectations rather than her behavior.

He might be in the wrong because he's holding a single incident to justify a larger change in their financial arrangement without considering the circumstances. She might not have the means to contribute much, and his reaction is disproportionate. The key points are the one-time event, her limited income, and the sudden shift in his stance without prior discussion. So, Answer A (Yes) might be correct because he's overreacting and not considering her financial situation.
